Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Cultural Interaction In Hierarchical Contexts

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The political expansion of large-scale complex societies is best understood as a dynamic between elite power and local innovation. Earlier studies of culture contact, migration, and political expansion have exaggerated the diffusion of cultural practices from a dominant core polity to its peripheral settlements. However, this emphasis on the core overlooks the experiences of local communities in culture contact situations, and the implications these interactions have on identity and everyday life. Dr. Gregory D. Wilson and Christina M. Friberg of the University of California, Santa Barbara (UCSB) will conduct archaeological research to evaluate how and why the complex Mississippian society of Cahokia (A.D. 1050-1375) extended its influence over the North American midcontinent and how the process of "Mississippianization" unfolded in the Lower Illinois River Valley (LIRV) of west-central Illinois. This research will highlight the complex process of culture contact whereby local peoples do not passively adopt the practices of a more powerful core polity, but engage, or resist engagement, in reference to their own identities. The project will also provide educational opportunities, and hands-on experience in both fieldwork and lab work, to undergraduate students, training them in the practical skills necessary to pursue a career in archaeology. Results will be shared with the scientific community through publication, and with local communities through public talks addressing the prehistory of their hometowns while stressing the importance of context and the scientific method in archaeology, as a means to discourage the widespread practice of looting.

Cahokia, near modern-day St. Louis, Missouri, was the largest PreColumbian city in North America and its inhabitants spread aspects of Mississippian culture as far north as northwest Wisconsin. However, little is understood about how Cahokians initiated these distant interactions, and how and why local groups participated in them. Settlements in Cahokia's American Bottom region of southwestern Illinois show evidence of direct political and economic ties with the paramount center of Cahokia. Archaeological research farther north has also shown that the inhabitants of frontier settlements selectively adopted certain aspects of a Mississippian way of life, while maintaining a number of their existing traditions. An analysis of craft production and exchange, subsistence patterns, and community organization at the Audrey North Site in the LIRV will add valuable insight to archaeologists' understanding of the Mississippian phenomenon in Cahokia's immediate periphery. The proximity of the LIRV to Cahokia likely facilitated regular interaction between the two regions, enabling certain social, political, and economic interactions with American Bottom groups that did not transpire with more distant groups. Using magnetic gradiometry data as a starting point, excavation should reveal evidence of the production and exchange of economically important Cahokian crafts. Bayesian statistical analysis of Radiocarbon assays will establish a timeline for the Mississippianization process in the LIRV. Finally, additional analysis of everyday practices such as food processing and storage and community organization will shed light on the degree to which local LIRV people incorporated Cahokian practices and/or maintained traditions with reference to their existing understanding of world order.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project was to assess Cahokia’s pan-regional influence, its implications for the negotiation of new identities and daily practices, and how the process of Mississippianization unfolded in the Lower Illinois River Valley (LIRV) of west-central Illinois. Contributing the growing body of theory on ross cultural encounters, this research highlights the negotiation of culture contact as a complex process whereby local peoples do not passively adopt the practices of a more powerful core polity, but engage, or resist engagement, in the active entanglement of new and local practices in reference to their own identities. This is accomplished through comparative analyses of architecture, pottery, and lithic tools from the Audrey site and sites in Cahokia’s American Bottom region and northern hinterland regions. The research has been disseminated in the form of public talks and conference proceedings, will form the basis for the co-PI’s doctoral dissertation, and eventually be adapted as a published manuscript. Finally, this project has created multiple educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students both in the field and in the lab.

From June 15th to August 1st 2016, the co-PI directed the Audrey Site Archaeological Project in Eldred, IL with funding from the National Science Foundation DDRI (award #1614379). With a crew of five people (including one undergraduate field student), she organized the excavation and mapping of two houses and multiple pit features. The field season was very successful, resulting in the collection of a large amount of data for her dissertation. At the end of the field season, preliminary results were presented at a public Summer Lecture Series at the Center for American Archaeology in Kampsville, Illinois.

The Audrey site is a large nucleated Mississippian village with Cahokia style architecture, including special purpose buildings, oriented to the same azimuth. From August 1st to December 15th 2016, materials from the site were analyzed at the University of California, Santa Barbara with a crew of five undergraduate interns. These students not only gained lab experience, but learned a lot about the analytical stage of the archaeological process (which is a rare opportunity for undergraduates). One of the students was influenced to complete a Senior Honors Thesis project with PI Wilson as her advisor. 

The Audrey site's pottery assemblage is made up of primarily early Sitrling phase (A.D. 1100-1150) Cahokia-style shell tempered jars. The presence of Mississippian-Woodland hybridity at northern hinterland Mississippian sites suggests inhabitants were retaining Woodland era methods of pottery production while incorporating only certain aspects of Cahokia inspired pottery. However, the current analysis found a lack of evidence for Woodland style influence in the ceramic assemblage. 

Samples from four features were submitted to the UC Irvine Keck Lab for AMS dating. The dates came from the Mississippian houses all fall within the expected range of 1040–1220 cal. A.D; ceramic analysis indicates a date of early Stirling phase (A.D. 1100–1150). A storage pit feature underneath one of the Mississippian houses dates to between 880–980 cal. A.D., placing the feature within the late Late Woodland Jersey Bluff phase, also as expected. This date is important because it confirms, as the lack of Woodland-Mississippian hybrid pottery suggests, that there is no temporal overlap between the Jersey Bluff and early Stirling phase components at Audrey.

The lithic assemblage at Audrey is essential to addressing questions related to the nature of political and economic interactions within the American Bottom, LIRV, and northern hinterland regions, particularly with regard to the production and or exchange certain Cahokian craft items. Evidence suggests that while Cahokia seems to have controlled these craft industries within the American Bottom, LIRV and northern hinterland groups were not directly engaged in these exchange networks. The exception are the Cahokia style basalt celts found at Audrey, which suggests that Audrey inhabitants had access to this craft industry, aiding in the clearing of agricultural fields and building their large Mississippian village. In contrast, analysis of projectile points suggests that Audrey inhabitants engaged in more frequent deer hunting than was possible in the American Bottom (due to resource depletion), and made expedient end scrapers for processing the hides, an uncommon activity in the American Bottom. 

Analysis of faunal material was completed by Steven Kuehn of the Illinois State Archaeological Survey and botanical analysis is still ongoing, conducted by Dana Bardolph at Cornell University. An interregional comparative analysis of faunal and botanical data is necessary to understand subsistence patterns at the Audrey site. This will be accomplished through future collaboration and publication. 

Portions of this research have been presented at the 2016 Southeastern Archaeology Conference (SEAC) in Athens, Georgia, the 2017 SEAC meetings in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and the 83rd Annual Meeting of the Society for American Archaeology in Washington DC. As analysis and dissertation writing are ongoing, research will be further disseminated through conference proceedings, journal articles, manuscripts, and future collaborative projects.
